channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tianjin Officials Struggle to Contain Fallout as Angry Relatives Demand Answers
item.description: A news conference in Tianjin was stormed by distraught relatives holding up lists of names, demanding information about dozens of missing firefighters.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: South Korean Leader Marks Anniversary of War’s End With Warnings to North Korea
item.description: Commemorating what South Koreans call Liberation Day, President Park Geun-hye said “provocations” from the North would “lead only to isolation and destruction.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye urged North Korea on Saturday to learn from Cuba’s moves to improve relations with the United States, saying the North had been “walking in the other direction.”

item.title: Brooklyn Man Accused of Supporting ISIS Pleads Guilty
item.description: Adburasul Hasanovich Juraboev, 25, who admitted to plotting to provide material to the Islamic State terrorist group, could face up to 15 years in prison.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: ISIS Held Kayla Mueller, U.S. Aid Worker, as Sex Slave Before Fatal Airstrike
item.description: Details of Ms. Mueller’s captivity, including her repeated rape by the leader of the Islamic State, were pieced together by American officials.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Matt Hinshaw/The Daily Courier, via Associated Press

item.title: ISIS Is Suspected of a Chemical Attack Against Kurds in Syria
item.description: If verified, the use of chemical agents could increase pressure on the Obama administration to intervene in the war more forcefully.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Police Suspected in Killings of 18
item.description: The Authorities in São Paulo said Friday that they were investigating whether police officers were involved in a series of execution-style killings.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Kerry Strikes Delicate Balance in Havana Trip for Embassy Flag-Raising
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry attended a ceremony at the diplomatic post, which officially opened in July, before talking to dissidents at a separate reception.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greeted the Marines who had lowered the flag at the United States Embassy in Havana in 1961.

item.title: Open Source: Internet Hoax on Downing of Malaysian Jet Spreads in Russia
item.description: In audio posted online this week by a Russian newspaper, a man identified as an American reporter working for the C.I.A. speaks in a British accent.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S.-Led Air Campaign Is Linked to Civilian Deaths in Syria
item.description: The episode revived accusations that the United States and its allies are not careful enough about who is killed by airstrikes on militant groups.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.media:description: Damage at a weapons factory operated by rebel fighters that was targeted in what activists said were American-led airstrikes on Atmeh, a Syrian village near the Turkish border.

item.title: Russian Publisher Rewrites Books on Putin Without Western Authors’ Consent
item.description: Western authors are finding that new versions of their books about Russia are appearing in bookstores there — rewritten and released without their permission.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: Luke Harding, a British journalist whose book was rewritten without his permission by a Russian publisher.

item.title: Chinese Independent Filmmakers Look to Locarno Festival
item.description: This event in Switzerland has become crucial for filmmakers who cannot get distribution for their movies in China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A still from "Kaili Blues," a feature from a young Chinese filmmaker that received its world premiere at the Locarno film festival.

item.title: Arab Bank Reaches Settlement in Suit Accusing It of Financing Terrorism
item.description: The deal, made with hundreds of American plaintiffs, comes after a jury in Brooklyn found the bank liable for dealings with the group Hamas; the court was to decide on damages starting Monday.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: U.N. Rights Experts Urge Iran to Free Washington Post’s Jason Rezaian
item.description: The experts’ statement came as a verdict was expected any day in the case of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been held since July 2014.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Is Poised to Oppose Freeing Guantánamo Hunger Striker
item.description: The Pentagon argues that if the government does not oppose any court-ordered release of Tariq Ba Odah, other detainees may go on hunger strikes.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Yemeni Government Faces Choice Between a Truce and Fighting On
item.description: Diplomats and analysts of the region warn against the optimism voiced by some Yemeni officials that the Houthi rebel movement is on the run.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA, KAREEM FAHIM and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Armored vehicles from the Saudi-led coalition near Aden, in southern Yemen, this month.

item.title: Shinzo Abe Echoes Japan’s Past World War II Apologies but Adds None
item.description: Mr. Abe’s statement on the eve of the 70th anniversary of the war’s end seemed intended to highlight what he and other conservatives see as an endless apology.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: People listened to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan as he gave a statement marking the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Daylight Killing Brings Beijing District of Sanlitun Under Scrutiny
item.description: The area is one of the capital’s most famous, an increasingly upscale place known for shopping, eating and drinking, but sometimes tinged with an edge of crime and violence.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: An article in China Newsweek said Sanlitun had “Beijing’s longest night,” where foreigners and Chinese party until morning.

item.title: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
item.description: The intern who said he could not afford housing in Geneva has called on unpaid interns around the world to unite, and the world body to live up to its own ideals.
item.category: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Death Toll in Chinese Fire Rises, Along With Anger at Apparent Safety Lapses
item.description: With laws requiring a 3,200-foot minimum distance from hazardous sites, new details emerging on Friday suggested possible criminal negligence.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Shipping containers remained in a smoldering pile on Friday, two days after the deadly fire in Tianjin, China. Bulldozers were being used to help clear paths.

item.title: Eurozone’s Economic Growth Falls Short, Even as Greeks Shopped
item.description: While Europe has faced a debt crisis in Greece, its bigger economies have been growing slowly as they recover from recession.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Jeroen Dijsselbloem, left, the Eurogroup president, greeted Euclid Tsakalotos, center, Greece’s finance minister, on Friday.
